title: Technical visits
text: On the 2nd day afternoon, there will be technical visits to some mobility companies that operate in Potugal.

title: Technical visits
text: Carris is the public operator of Lisbon urban bus, tram and funicular services. Founded in 1872, it transports more than 130 million passengers every year.  This visit will take the participants to the operational control center and the buses workshop.  Schedule: 15:00 to 17:00 | Openings: 25 participants

title: Technical visits
text: Infraestruturas de Portugal is the public company responsible for managing the Portuguese road and rail infrastructure.  In this visit, the participants will have the opportunity to get to know the Lisbon rail operational control center, managing most of the national infrastructure.  Schedule: 15:00 to 17:00 | Openings: 25 participants

title: Technical visits
text:
GIRA is Lisbon’s public bike system. Operating since 2017, it already counts with 188 dock stations, that provide more than 2000 bicycles to live and explore the city.  The visit will allow the participants to explore the system control center and the bicycles workshop.  Schedule: 15:00 to 17:00 | Openings: 25 participants







Carris bus and tram







Rail control center







GIRA bicycle

title: 8-9th Sept. | Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research
text: Robin Lovelace (University of Leeds) & Juan Fonseca-Zamora (University of Leeds)

title: 8-9th Sept. | Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research
text: Robin Lovelace (University of Leeds) & Juan Fonseca-Zamora (University of Leeds)

title: 8-9th Sept. | Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research
text:
Learning objectives

Be able to share reproducible code for more scientific and transparent transport research
To be confident reproducing your own work and that of others
To become skilled at using Git and GitHub to manage versions of your code and collaborate with others
To be able to write reproducible content that can be exported to a variety of formats with the Quarto system for scientific publishing
To understand how Quarto extensions can be used as a basis for creating publication-ready papers
To be aware of ‘continuous integration’ and ‘GitHub Actions’ and how they can be used to ensure reproducibility, share your work, and save time
Understanding of best practices around code sharing and collaboration for reproducible research in transport planning

title: 8-9th Sept. | Tools and Skills for Reproducible Transport Research

title: 13-14th Sept. | Qualitative Methods in Urban Mobility Research
text: Hannah Hook (Ghent University, Department of Geography)

title: 13-14th Sept. | Qualitative Methods in Urban Mobility Research
text: Hannah Hook (Ghent University, Department of Geography)

title: 13-14th Sept. | Qualitative Methods in Urban Mobility Research
text:
Learning objectives

Introduce doctoral researchers to the basic techniques of qualitative methods and provide knowledge on how to perform reproducible research.
Provide doctoral researchers with the skills to design research and data collection protocols.
Explain how technological transitions, such as the invention of GenAI, can affect qualitative research, and the implications for biases and ethics.

title: Hannah Hook
text: Hannah Hook is DTN Alumni and will soon start an Assistant Professor position of Sustainable Land Use and Transport Planning in the Department of the Built Environment at Aalto University, Finland. She completed her PhD and is currently a postdoctoral researcher at Ghent University, and previously completed two Master’s degrees in GIS Technology (University of Arizona ) and Sustainable Cities (King’s College London) and two Bachelor’s degrees in Sustainability and Business Communications (Arizona State University). Her research focuses on the role of discretionary and undirected travel in promoting well-being, travel satisfaction, and transport equity. Hannah’s work bridges mobility behaviour, the built environment, and social sustainability.

title: Getting to Lisbon
text:
Lisbon international airport (Humberto Delgado Airport) connects the world with the city and has a direct connection to its transportation system, through the metro red line.



Lisbon airport

title: Getting to Lisbon
text:
Lisbon international airport (Humberto Delgado Airport) connects the world with the city and has a direct connection to its transportation system, through the metro red line.



Lisbon airport

title: Getting to Lisbon
text:
By train
Lisbon has two main stations for long distance services. Despite not having direct connections with foreign countries, if you come from anywhere in Portugal you can get here by picking a train with destination Lisboa Santa Apolónia if you come from the north or Lisboa Oriente if you come from the south. Both stations are connected to the metro network and urban railway services.



Gare do Oriente Station

title: Getting to Lisbon
text:
By bus
An alternative to get to Lisbon are the long distance buses, covering Portugal mainland, Spain and even France. At Lisbon, they get to Sete Rios or Gare do Oriente. Both stations are connected to the metro network.



Sete Rios station

title: Getting to the venue
text:
The DTN Annual Forum 2025 will be hosted at Institute of Geography and Spatial Planning (IGOT). It is located in the University of Lisbon campus in heart of Lisbon city, accessible by several transport modes.
This page specifies the transport interfaces that are closest to the DTN venue. For more details on Lisbon transportation system network, apps and prices, refer to Getting around.

title: Getting to the venue
text:
By bike
IGOT is accessible through the city cycle lane infrastructure.
There is a station from the public bike system right outside the venue. Its number is 461 - Rua Professor Teresa Ambrósio. Find the stations map at GIRA website.
You can also park an e-scooter or any other shared mobility vehicle right outside. They are allowed inside the campus.

title: Getting to the venue
text:
By train/metro
IGOT is just a 15 minutes walk from Entrecampos interface. There you can catch an urban train to almost anywhere in Lisbon metropolitan area.
This interface also connects to metro. There you can catch the yellow line and easily connect to the others (2 stations away from green and red lines, 4 from the blue line).
Regarding metro, the stippness of the terrain in this area makes Entrecampos a better option to leave the venue. To get there, Cidade Universitária metro station is a better option.

title: Getting to the venue
text:
By bus
IGOT is served by several lines of the urban bus operator, Carris, connecting to almost anywhere in the city: 701, 731, 732, 735, 738, 754, 755, 764 and 768.
There is also a suburban bus that serves it, 3702 from operator Carris Metropolitana, connecting to Almada, in the south bank of Lisbon metro area.






IGOT building has a GIRA (public bike system) station next to it







You can also park any shared mobility vehicle right outside









Entrecampos train/metro interface is a 15 minutes walk from the venue

title: Getting around
text: Lisbon is serviced by a robust transportation system, build up on metro, bus, trams and urban trains. Here we list the main means of transportation and how you can use them.

title: Getting around
text:
Means of transportation




Walking
The best way to get around the city. Get on your feet and explore!



Cycling
Lisbon has 128km of dedicated cycle lanes. Discover the network at ciclovias.pt!  You can ride them using the public bike system, GIRA. It has a fee of only 2€/day, including unlimited trips up to 30 minutes (+2€ per 45-90’). Download the app and get a bike here!



Metro
Metro is the quickest way to cover distances inside the city. Find out more at Metro de Lisboa website.



Bus/tram/lift
Buses cover the entire city, complementing the metro network for less dense areas accessibility. Trams and lifts allow you to discover the city hills and Belém. Discover the network at Carris website.

title: Getting around
text:
Tickets
Trips can be payed with contactless cards, being charged the same amount as for the board ticket. However, you can buy a Zapping card (0,50€ per card, one card per person) at the Metro machines and top it up with 3, 5 or 10€. Using this card, the individual trips are cheaper on buses and trams.




Contactless/board ticket
Zapping


Metro
1,85€
1,66€


Bus
2,20€
1,85 €


Tram
3,20€
1,85 €


Lifts
4,20€
1,85€



As an alternative, you can buy a 24 hour card (at the Metro machines) valid for the whole network (metro+bus+tram+lifts), for only 7,00€.

title: Getting around
text:
Apps
Below you can find some apps that integrate information about Lisbon transportation system, allowing you to find the best route and track vehicles in real time!

title: Venue
text:
The DTN Annual Forum 2025 will be hosted at Institute of Geography and Spatial Planning (IGOT). It is located in the heart of Lisbon city and inside University of Lisbon campus, accessible by several transport modes. For more details on how to get to Lisbon, to the venue and around the city, check the respective pages.

IGOT has a prominent and consolidated position in geography teaching and researching in Portugal, focusing on areas such as social and earth sciences, planning, spatial planning and management.
Their facilities will host DTN Annual Forum 2025, specifically, the Orlando Ribeiro auditorium.



Orlando Ribeiro auditorium

title: Guides
text:
Lisbon is more than a city. It is a broad and whole territory waiting to be explored. In this page we share with you some touristic guides that may be of your interest.








  




Turismo de Lisboa







Website




The institutional page for Lisboa tourism association. Here you can find several informations about the main attractions, events and practical tips.






https://www.visitlisboa.com/en






  




Visit a city







App




This app provides several itineraries addapted to diverse preferences and durations.






https://www.visitacity.com/en/lisbon






  




TimeOut







Website




This magazine compiles several guides that can help you find the best viewpoints, museums or beaches.






https://www.timeout.com/lisbon/things-to-do
